title: Will Turkey impose capital controls before 1 December 2016 ?
preds: Considering the turkish economy structure, i think it would not be possible over the period of 3 years.

Norman and Peker (2016) Nov. 24, state that: The European Parliament overwhelmingly called for a temporary freeze in talks on Turkey’s bid to join the European Union on Thursday, citing what it said were deteriorating human rights and democratic standards under President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s rule. Turkey’s EU Affairs Minister Omer Celik swiftly slammed the nonbinding vote as politically motivated, criticizing the lawmakers as succumbing to xenophobia and failing to grasp the threats facing his country following a failed coup targeting Mr. Erdogan’s government (para. 1-2). The intense debate in Turkey about transition from the country’s parliamentary democracy to a presidential system is having a negative impact on the national economy, Turkish economist and journalist Erdal Saglam told Sputnik.
"The industrial production in Turkey is maintained from the outside with money inflows. But we see that the economy is slowing down due to a drop in capital inflows to Turkey. The reasons are global economic trends as well as Turkish domestic political and economic problems," the economist pointed out.
Earlier this year, the Turkish government predicted a five percent growth, but then the outlook was adjusted to three percent. This has had a direct impact on people and their consumption.
"This trend is more visible in certain sectors, and in some it is less visible. But overall it is having a negative impact on the economy. Many major companies have been shutting down. 
Read more: https://sputniknews.com/business/201610291046874500-erdogan-turkish-economy/

“I have two simple messages to speculators: Turkey to maintain sound macroeconomic policies,” Mehmet Şimşek tweeted late July 19, adding: “Capital controls are out of the question.”        
http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkish-capital-controls-out-of-the-question-deputy-pm-simsek.aspx?pageID=238&nID=101863&NewsCatID=345 Turkey has a reasonable Credit Rating
http://www.tradingeconomics.com/turkey/rating Sudden Stops and Capital Controls: When to Apply in Turkey
http://ccsenet.org/journal/index.php/ijef/article/view/57200/31270 Five sudden stop periods with providing all the above mentioned were identified. August 1998 with Russian
crisis, November 2000 crisis starting with liquidity problems, the deepening February 2001 crisis, March 2003 period where 1 March resolution regarding sending troops to Iraq was refused by the Turkish Parliament and May 2006 with the global fluctuation come forward as sudden stop periods in Turkey. "i- The capital flow decrease at any month during the sudden stop period must be at least two standard deviations
below the average. In other words, the below inequality must be provided;
Capital flow decrease ≥ (capital flow average - 2 x capital flow standard deviation)
ii- The sudden stop period begins when the capital flow decrease at any month is at least one standard deviation
below the average. In other words, the below inequality must be provided;
Capital flow decrease ≥ (capital flow average - capital flow volatility)
iii- The sudden stop period ends when the capital flow decrease at any month is at least one standard deviation
above the average. In other words, the below inequality must be provided;
Capital flow decrease ≤ (capital flow average - capital flow volatility)" None of the current conditions satisfy the criteria set out by economists as when Turkey would be better off applying capital controls.
Think I was way too high initially.

Am reducing from 1 to 0% the risk of Turkish Capital controls. Here is why. Comment: Released this morning: politicians do NOT impose capital controls on an economy that is growing at a well above average ME pace.
http://m.yenisafak.com/en/economy/turkeys-economy-records-over-3-percent-growth-2528892 More fundamentally, "time is now of the essence" as there are less than ninety (90) days for resolution of this GJ Q. Imposition of capital controls IS a major event seldom used and, often times with shorter term dire economic consequences for the country's population.(FN1)  It often leads to significant change in the existing  political leadership, an element Erdogan is very aware of. Considering the resolution date of this Q, this fact has now become a critical factor, when one takes the totality of events taking place since the failed military coup into consideration when forecasting the probability of this event.  For example, on the one hand, Erdogan like  Putin, has cleverly taken advantage of a concerned public by instilling a majoritarian form of nationalism that has commonality to a security state. (2). The Turks are a proud people yet remain, as most in EU, very sensitive to terrorism & immigrant issues. Erdogan has played good politics to these sensitivities,  in many ways unleashing a sense of greater nationalism.  More Erdogan control, yes. A complete clamp down, including capital controls, no. On the other hand, every external measure taken by Erdogan speaks to an unmistakable effort being made to conduct business with foreign partners, albeit with a clear tilt towards non EU & US partners. Whether it be w/ the Russians to further develop funding for the AKKUYU Nuclear Power Plant or, the Sino-Turkish parliamentary ratification cooperation on peaceful uses of nuclear energy, the economic picture is clear. (3)  Turkish Government has no intention taking on inward looking measures such as capital controls. Late in July, they made this announcement explicitly. (4) Government still is absolutely convinced business development abroad continues to be an important key towards economic development. (5) Indeed, the Turkish Chamber of Commerce these days "pitches" the "we are stronger post the coup" claim. (6) Conclusion:  On the one hand, Erdogan is Erdogan so, there is always a "capital control"uncertainty argument. Importantly, however, balanced  against this argument,  Erdogan has out maneuvered the EU leaving it in a difficult corner over the so called EU Turkey immigration deal.  On this score alone, Erdogan is cleverly playing his financial package in hand. Imposition of capital controls would blow both a financial & political hole to his body politic.  NATO's chief Stolenberg even WELCOMED Turkey's right to defend itself against IS. Further geopolitical evidence slapping capital controls at this stage is simply out of question.(7) Considering all of the above-mentioned, in a sum of the parts weighted analysis, leaves one with little room for doubt: a) Erdogan's Turkey needs to get back on economic track which it has proven in the past that it can, b) Erdogan has every intention of strengthening his hand and stay in Turkey; and, c) he can only assure his position by walking this fine line of economic development on the one hand &, and maintaining his political capital through establishing his people his is making every reasonable effort to bring Turkish economic interests towards equilibrium. UNDER these circumstances, CAPITAL CONTROLS have no place. The implications are clear. A Greek or Cyprus like imposition of capital controls in Erdogan's Turkey w/in the NEXT ninety (90) days is a zero (0) probability event. SOURCES////
(1) http://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/capital_conrol.asp; http://www.economist.com/blogs/economist-explains/2015/06/economist-explains-21;     http://www.economist.com/news/finance-and-economics/21598649-bail-out-working-bail-isnt-injured-island;
(2)http://pulitzercenter.org/reporting/welcome-demokrasi-how-erdogan-got-more-popular-ever (NB: EXCELLENT READ 4 those interested!)
(3)http://en.trend.az/business/energy/2654978.html; http://m.sputniknews.com/middleeast/20160901/1044832084/turkey-china-nuclear.html
(4)http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkish-capital-controls-out-of-the-question-deputy-pm-simsek.aspx?pageID=517&nID=101863&NewsCatID=345
(5) http://www.dailysabah.com/politics/2016/08/22/following-july-15-turkey-will-transform-into-one-of-the-most-developed-democracies-in-the-world; 
http://www.worldbulletin.net/headlines/176053/turkey-in-pursuit-of-24b-foreign-investment
(6) Turkish economy 'stronger after coup': Chambers head from ANADOLU AGENCY (ENG)’s Tweet
(7)http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-turkey-idUSKCN11F0RV?il=0

The last thing Turkey wants to do now is a move that further destabilizes the country and reduce confidence in the president. Turkish capital controls “are out of the question”, the country’s deputy prime minister has said. "I have two simple messages to speculators: Turkey to maintain sound macroeconomic policies," Mehmet Simsek tweeted late Tuesday, adding: "Capital controls are out of the question." A country can use capital controls to order its banks to impose strict limits on daily withdrawals and foreign country transfers of cash. "[Turkey’s] banking sector is well capitalized and has strong asset quality," Simsek also tweeted. The country's top economic officials have been trying to reassure investors that Friday’s failed coup will not cause permanent damage to the economy.

Capital Controls Reducing my already below average 5% down to 1%. Here is why. Comment: One the one hand, the West is correct to view w/ caution the strong arm tactics Erdogan has taken advantage of post the unsuccessful Military Coup. http://app.ft.com/cms/s/bbcd39ba-5b0d-11e6-9f70-badea1b336d4.html?ftcamp=crm/email//nbe/FirstFTAsia/product&siteedition=intl. Geopolitical considerations mandate a careful &, cautious approach to the new developments btw Putin & Erdogan.  That said, a careful consideration of CAPITAL CONTROLS must be given proper consideration. http://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/capital_conrol.asp; https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_control.  Under the present circumstances, there is LITTLE to NO probability Erdogan will impose capital controls, under these classical definitions, so long as he continues to extend his frame of reference towards improving the economic opportunities for Turkey. Erdogan has a significant financial & political interest to assure both a free flow of tourism, the capital & business development as he extends he extends his effort  w/ Putin in St. Petersburg. http://m.sputniknews.com/europe/20160809/1044094924/putin-ankara-akkuyu-stream.html To do otherwise, under the above-mentioned circumstances would in a) the first instance a COMPLETE LOSS of credibility w/ Putin &, b) secondly a COMPLETE LOSS of credibility w/ his voting public that clearly are v/ supportive of him as of today.

A decisive stance in the coming days will help lower economic risks in the country, he said, adding that the concerns of the international rating agencies will be dissipated within the next few days.

Date: 20. Juli 2016 um 22:12:14 MESZ Subject: Turkish capital controls 'out of the question' COMMENT: On the ONE hand, the attached SPEAKS for itself. Nonetheless, for SHORT speculators reference the Turkish lira on the one hand,  a feast so long as Erdogan continues his assumption of full political control approach.  The attempted unsuccessful Military Coup on the other hand, has a lasting side effect which include the risk of recession relative to its previously strong GNP growth fundamentals and, lower corporate profits for most mid to small sized Turkish companies, due not as much to a weaker Lira rather, as the political uncertainty created by Erdogan's iron fist approach to regaining political/military control.  A bad mix.  On the OTHER  hand, NB: "when it becomes serious, you lie" said EC President Jean Claude Junker! Turkey is, at least, implementing "shadow" controls such as restricted amount that can be taken out of country on travel, or amount that can be charged to credit cards abroad.  What concerns me is the completely opposite numbers from different sources that reference Turkey (IEconmics vs Tradingeconomics). Inflation rates. Bond ratings. Foreign reserves, etc, etc. One will say inflation is going down, the other is saying inflation is going up. [Trading economics]: Foreign reserves have declined over last year from approx $144B USD to $127B USD. Govt bonds rated BB+ by S&P(Non-investment grade
speculative) (negative outlook); or Baa3 by Moody's (stable) (Lower medium grade). Fitch has a reported rating of BBB- (negative) for Turkey. (April 2016)

Although Turkey has a tough geographic address right now, the economic stats feel fine.  They continue to have a negative outlook from the rating agencies but remain BB+, Baa3 & BBB-.  Capital flows have moderated after some bumps last year, business confidence remains fine, consumer confidence has stabilized, rates and fx are in familiar ranges, growth and unemployment could improve but are not cautionary.  Hence, an okay economic situation with a lot of turmoil from the geographic location which is supported by the key they provide to the EU and US. imposing capital controls is rare enough. Iran may open up as a trade partner in the upcoming months.  Biggest issue that I see is potential downfall of the EU, which is a non-zero possibility. And anything can happen before years' end. no way to make a truly accurate prediction right now, and at least one analytic firm put the odds at 50-50 by years end.

While the global economy is not in a good way, and Turkey is more susceptible than most economies to terrorism and sensitive to crises in China, I agree with others here - it would be a big step, and arguably a counter-productive one. I think Turkey will ride it out. There will likely be other measures the government can take short of capital controls to help buoy the economy in the medium term (interest rates, taxes, etc).

Capital controls have been imposed very infrequently as compared to how often financial problems appear.  In particular, the last decade or so there have been capital controls to Greece, Cyprus, Argentina and Iceland.  All of these countries also have a very small economy (Argentina might be a small outlier). Turkey is clearly a larger economy as compared to Greece, Cyprus and Iceland (and potentially Argentina) and hence, capital controls might really paralyze the whole financial and economic sector.  Hence, I give a very small probability of capital controls being imposed in Turkey.

I'll stick it out here for a while. If China were to announce a tightening of capital controls, or had a big bang devaluation  or both, I think there would be a stampede for the EM exits and Turkey would have to impose cap controls. Otherwise things seem to be hanging fire generally, so I may want to revise this probability downwards for the time period of this question

In addition to what austerity excerpted:  Dateline 1-14-16 Unable to stop the economic hemorrhage sparked by the flight of foreign investors and money, Turkey’s government has tightened the country’s 26-year liberal foreign exchange rules. Travelers exiting Turkey are now required to make declarations of cash and credit cards or face sanctions on charges of money laundering and smuggling. http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/01/turkey-tightens-foreign-currency-rules.html

I'm not sure this qualifies as "capital controls", but looks a step in that direction http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/01/turkey-tightens-foreign-currency-rules.html?src=ilaw#
"According to the Central Bank’s balance of payments report for the third quarter of 2015, announced Jan. 5, the bank’s foreign exchange reserves dropped by $1.1 billion to $119.6 billion despite the inflow of $7.8 billion from "unknown sources." Alarmed by its failure to reverse the trend, the government took a fresh step Dec. 30, amending Decree No. 32 on the protection of the value of Turkish currency, enacted in 1989 as a milestone step liberalizing the foreign exchange market in Turkey.
...
Under the Dec. 30 amendment, travelers exiting Turkey with cash of more than 25,000 lira ($8,263) or more than 10,000 euros or an equivalent sum of foreign currency are now obliged to declare the money to customs at airports and border crossings. A newly added provision says that in cases where the money is not declared, or incorrect or misleading declarations are made, the money in question will be taken by customs and considered suspicious. Customs officials will then notify MASAK and refer the case also to prosecutors on charges of trafficking. The amendment covers also “documents enabling payment in Turkish lira,” which means that credit cards with a limit of more than 25,000 Turkish lira are also up for declaration."

This is a hard question. For me it is easier to split it in two questions: 1-	What are the odds of Turkey being in trouble until the end of 2016?
2-	If Turkey get in trouble, what are the odds of Turkey government imposing capital controls? Second question seems easier to answer than the first one. It is very probable that Turkey government will impose capital controls in case of a grave crisis, since IMF is starting to acknowledge capital controls as a valid politic to manage financial crisis and Erdrogan is a traditional populist. However, the odds of capital control is smaller in a not-so hard crisis and it lowers when crisis severity drops. About the first question, 2016 does not look like a great year for emerging countries. There is Eurozone crisis, Dollar strengthening, IE war, China slowdown and oil prices. Each one of these alone have the potential to increase investors risk aversion and Turkey is one of the countries most affected by it thanks to heavy external borrowing dependence. It is always hard to prevent when this kind of event will happen, but 2016 seems an year with higher than average odds of an adverse event affecting Turkey. http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/survey/so/2012/POL120312A.htm

That said, ongoing geopolitical risks and the possibility that the Central Bank will have to tighten its monetary policy further in order to protect the lira represent the main downside risks to Turkey’s outlook. For this year, the panel also expects the economy to expand 3.0%. COOMENT: it is early to say. Capital controls is a hard step to take and we should hear alarm bells way before it happens.

Imposing capital controls are a significant sign that the country is in severe stress and that the options available are few.  No question their address is in a turbulent part of the world and the mass refugee crisis is a significant strain.  On the positive side, they are seeing positive credit growth to private companies and households.  In addition, they are a benefactor of low oil prices, current negotiations with the EU on the refugee crisis, they don't really have an exposure to Chinese growth, and they are an important location for military presence for the ISIS fight.
Nobody much likes capital controls, but in the coming months Turkey has more reasons to resort to them than just about anybody else.
Ongoing strife in region. Syrian refugee crisis draining resources. Econ gloom becomes downward spiral. Capital controls imposed in attempt to strengthen.

Capital controls are a drastic step and not taken lightly. In recent years, Iceland, Cyprus, Greece have taken this step in response to very acute situations. Otherwise, ther are not that many examples aside from significantly less developed economies in Africa etc.  Capital controls do not happen often in relatively sophistical economies and when they do it is usually in response to an acute situation that has developed over a significant amount of time rather than as a shock response. In each of these cases (Cyprus, Greece etc.), 5yr CDS (5 year debt insurance contracts) traded at well in excess of 10% per annum  (ie it would cost you 10%+ per year of the insured sum to insure against default of the debt issuing country) at the time of the capital control introduction.  This is quite a significant level of distress (ie holders of debt are willing to commit to paying 10% per year for 5yrs of the amount they are insuring - would you pay a total of 50% (10% per year for 5yrs) of your house value for fire insurance? Not unless that wild fire was already burning down the house next door!).  CDS contracts are a pretty good indication of the likelihood of Turkey default - which is a fair parallel to the likelihood of capital controls being introduced as an attempt to avoid such a default.  At the moment, Turkey 5yr CDS trades at 2.6%. This is elevated, but much better than Brazil (5%) or South Africa (3.2%).  CDS contracts will very likely trade at elevated levels well ahead of capital controls being introduced, so this is an effective lead indicator for this question. The Fed has now hiked and in fact Turkey 5yr CDS traded LOWER. This is despite the expectation of several more hikes in the year ahead. Capital outflows from Turkey are very unlikely to be so significant as to warrant controls. I regard the probability here as very low on such a relatively short horizon.

Given the Fed just raised rates, one must adjust the odds of this higher. Without parsing Yellen's statement here, assuming the Fed gets to their target of 3.5% for the Federal-funds rate; there's a reasonable chance this change in interest rate differential could ignite a wider emerging market selloff. This is a contingent probability outcome, one which comes down to interpreting or empathising with Erdogan's reaction function. To have greater clarity, one would need to get an idea of his economic beliefs to inform this position.  I have chosen 44% because I'm assuming the Fed hikes gradually over the next 24 months further impairing emerging market currency regimes.

Current Account Balance to GDP is high (CAB/GDP), which means internal savings is too low. Economies which cannot provide enough money to finance their investments, have to attract foreign capital. 
The strength of the Turkish Lira has strengthened since 2003. http://article.sapub.org/image/10.5923.j.economics.20140406.02_008.gif.  Overvaluation of domestic currency increases consumption and importation, and reduces export values.
Short term debt percentage since 1994 has drastically declined (98% vs.5%). This improves the capability of a country to create a smoother international borrowing structure. In general, Turkish economy is not well situated for a capital controls scenario. Internal structural and financial adjustments are their best path, probably with close coordination of the IMF. One condition that may cause a capital control scenario is an asymmetrical hot money  event. A serious political event could be a trigger.

Turkey's spat with Russia is going to exacerbate their growing economic woes. The underlying problem there, and in many other EM countries is the combination of a strong US dollar and weak commodity prices; this is hurting many of their traditional trading partners. In addition, all of the major economies are doing their darnedest to export deflation (i.e. prop up their own economies by printing money), and this is hurting smaller countries. If the governor of India's central bank isn't sleeping well at night, then smaller economies are going to be in even tougher shape. Having lived in, and traveled to a number of countries with capital controls, I can say that this isn't a rare scenario at all (and yes, everyone tries to evade them anyway, and they cause havoc when trying to remove them afterwards - they're usually a good indication of either desperation or financial mismanagement). The current list of countries with capital controls in place includes Turkey's neighbor (occasional enemy, and also former third-largest trading partner!) Greece. We're going to see many emerging market countries impose controls in the next few years. I'm going to start high, and gradually reduce over time, if there's no further news.

http://news.markets/bonds/emerging-market-investors-should-keep-a-close-eye-on-turkey-3335/
"Turkey’s weak fundamentals, high debt levels, and sensitivity to capital flow volatility mean an increased risk of capital controls being introduced there, according to Fay Ren, investment analyst at fund manager Cerno Capital.
. . .
“Nonetheless, the end of quantitative easing and the expectation of rate rises in the US may see a reversal of the trend of flows that have been fundamental to Turkey’s economy; signs of this are just beginning to emerge. This will make funding more expensive and debt more difficult to repay, thus making Turkey more vulnerable to capital flight, taking into consideration that almost 25% of their bonds are held by foreigners. These eventualities are often precursors to the introduction of the foreign investor’s nemesis – capital controls,” Ren adds."
